Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Doping Control and Processes in Metal Halide Perovskites
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: Metal halide perovskites refer to a class of semiconductors that have recently achieved an exceptional rate of performance improvement for use in light-emitting devices, photodetectors and solar cells. The combination of excellent performance and facile solution processing open new opportunities for low-cost high-performance electronic devices. While these materials have enjoyed extensive success for application in electronic devices, further improvement is limited in part by a lack of understanding of how to control the number of electrical carriers within the semiconductor (known as doping), which is a vital parameter for establishing device operation. By creating a broadly interdisciplinary project, employing both theory and experimental approaches, the current research seeks to develop a better understanding of doping processes for controlling the level of electrons/holes within this important class of halide perovskites. By achieving the goals of the project, novel designs of higher-efficiency solar cells and light-emitting devices, as well as higher-performance perovskite transistors are expected. Undergraduate, graduate and postdoc researchers play a pivotal role in the multidisciplinary project execution and the project therefore plays a vital role in training future scientists. As a GOALI project, a critical aspect involves broadening student experiences to include industrial research exposure, as well as creating a link to the world-leading materials characterization capabilities within industry.

Technical Description: Semiconductor doping using intrinsic/extrinsic crystalline defects establishes the energy levels and carrier densities that determine optoelectronic properties. High-performance photovoltaic materials, for example, rely on careful doping control to modify the electronic properties and improve the device performance to levels approaching the Shockley-Queisser limit. Although metal halide perovskites have received much attention recently, due to the exceptional rise in associated photovoltaic performance, the current understanding and exploration of doping in this class of complex ionic semiconductors remains limited. This project paves the way for more tunable functional halide perovskites by addressing important doping related questions, such as: (1) can the relatively 'soft' nature of metal halide perovskites create special challenges and opportunities for development of new doping pathways; (2) can the use of complexes rather than individual ions enhance doping tenability; and (3) what opportunity for molecular doping exist within the organic cation layer versus impurity doping within the metal halide framework? In order to develop this critical understanding, the project integrates academic and industrial research in materials synthesis, optoelectronic characterization and theory to investigate dopant incorporation and activation in perovskite semiconductors. The research consists of several thrusts, including: (1) theory/computation-guided development of new dopants and doping processes, (2) exploration of molecular dopants in hybrid perovskites, (3) manipulation of radiative recombination using doping and (4) application of unique electrical transport characterization tools, developed by the industrial partner, to understand doping in halide perovskites and also to provide a framework for future study of transport phenomena in complex materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrical doping underlies most successful energy-related and optoelectronic technologies, such as solar cells and light-emitting devices, enabling necessary tunability in semiconductor junctions and at interfaces with electrodes, as well as fine tuning of the transport properties. While today's knowledge allows good control over doping in some strictly inorganic semiconductors such as silicon, and good progress has been made to dope organic systems, it is equally important to control electronic properties of the promising hybrid halide perovskite semiconductor family. While first evidence of strong doping in halide perovskites was obtained early in the emergence of the halide perovskite field for optoelectronic applications, with semimetallic conductivities reached for tin-based compounds, precise and effective tuning of doping type and level in tin and other halide perovskites has proven particularly challenging and remains a significant bottleneck in the development of perovskite-based technologies. The current GOALI project, which combines experimental and computational expertise at Duke University and IBM Corporation, sought to address this challenge by seeking a deeper understanding of doping in this important materials family.

Key to examining the doping process in halide perovskites is the need for experimental techniques to study the changing character of the charge carriers resulting from the doping process. The Hall effect is the foundation of one of the most important characterization techniques to uncover fundamental information about the majority charge carriers but presents significant challenges for evaluation of highly resistive materials such as perovskites. In the current project, we used a recently IBM-developed rotating parallel dipole line (PDL) ac field Hall system to probe Hall signals in perovskite semiconductors and reliably extract majority carrier density values. While majority carrier properties are important, solar cell and related optoelectronic devices typically also depend critically on minority carrier properties, including recombination lifetime and diffusion lengths, which doping may also impact. One of the key outcomes of this project is the development and usage of the new carrier-resolved photo-Hall (CRPH) technique, as described in a recent Nature publication. This new approach was shown to provide access to relevant majority and minority carrier properties, all within the same perovskite samples and all as a function of light intensity. The CRPH approach is expected to be of significant interest in the broader evaluation of emerging and established semiconductors being pursued for a wide range of optoelectronic and energy-related technologies. 

Three strategies can be identified for perovskite doping: extrinsic defect doping, intrinsic defect doping and charge transfer doping. All three strategies have been explored throughout this project using collaborative experimental and computational  efforts. Extrinsic defect doping has proven particularly challenging, raising several questions regarding the ability to effectively introduce impurity atoms in the structure and the tendency for compensation to counteract charged defects. Recent theoretical efforts within the program point to the possibility of using bismuth as a dopant in lead-based perovskites, under selected processing conditions. As an alternative to extrinsic defect doping, intrinsic defects can be tuned through precursor ratio variations and provide a means of controlling electrical properties in halide perovskites. In our program, we reported p-type doping imparted by PbI2 addition in MAPbI3, along with substantial improvement of the minority carrier lifetime, as determined by CRPH analysis. This approach was further used to achieve high performance perovskite solar cells using a device structure that does not contain an electron transport layer, of interest for reducing the cost of perovskite solar cells. Nevertheless, intrinsic defects offer a limited doping range due to prevalent strong compensation effects. Charge transfer doping with molecular dopants appears among the most promising techniques for perovskites. While research on integrated molecular dopants in perovskite films has so far only yielded modest conductivity enhancement, we showed for the first time a halide perovskite conductivity tuning range of up to 5 orders of magnitude using a molecular dopant that coats grain boundaries. As doubts remain about the ability to reliably control doping in halide perovskites, our study highlights the potential of molecular doping to effectively address this problem and opens the door to future in-depth studies towards optimization of the doping.

With the knowledge acquired on perovskite electrical doping throughout the project, we have written a comprehensive review article on the subject and currently this manuscript is accepted and in the editing stage at Nature Reviews Materials. The review article discusses strategies for halide perovskite doping and takes a critical look at the challenges that remain for control of electronic properties within this important emerging semiconductor family. Additionally, the project resulted in 7 peer-reviewed publications and numerous contributed and invited lectures at domestic and international conferences.  The project also contributed to the training of 4 PhD students, 3 postdoctoral researchers and provided extended research experiences for 2 undergraduate students.
